title.narrative: Rädda Barnen SRHR information och utbildning Project
Save the Children SRHR information & Education Project.

description.narrative:
Rädda Barnen Sverige i samarbete med Regionala Rädda Barnen för östra och södra Afrika föreslår ett projekt som kommer att arbeta för att förbättra barn och ungas tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter som ett sätt att påverka grundläggande orsaker till hiv och aids. Projektet kommer att svara mot utmaningar som barn, ungdomar och i allmänhet ungdomar i östra och södra Afrika (ESA) regionen står inför när det gäller tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR). Ungdomar i ESA-regionen fortsätter att brottas med olika problem som rör till gång till SRHR och hiv. Nya studier som visar direkt samband mellan hiv och brist på SRHR, som i sin tur leder till sjukdom och dödlighet bland ungdomar. Det finns det ett behov för väl utformade insatser för att ta itu med dessa två områden bland ungdomar. Projektet kommer att arbeta för att skapa en gynnsam miljö och lindra de problem som hindrar ungdomars goda hälsa. Problemen omfattar oroväckande högt anta nya hiv infektioner bland unga människor, särskilt flickor, svaga och splittrade vård- och omsorgssystem som är vertikala och okänsliga för behoven hos barn och ungdomar, låg hiv-testning, och kritiska hinder för ungdomar få tillgång till vård och behandling; låg tillgång till och användning av preventivmedel bland ungdomar; hög fertilitet bland unga flickor; tidig sexuell debut bland ung; hög förekomst av riskbeteende bland annat oskyddat sex, flera samtidiga partnerskap, sexuella relationer över generationer och med materiella transaktioner; otillräcklig information och kunskap om sexualitet och hur man skyddar sig; högt antal oönskade graviditeter bland flickor; hög nivå av mödradödligheten bland unga mödrar; tidiga äktenskap för unga kvinnor och flickor; och en ovilja och ibland oförmåga hos föräldrar och vårdgivare att kommunicera med barn om alla aspekter av sexualitet, och därmed en brist på SRHR utbildning för alla åldrar. Projektet kommer att investera i att tillhandahålla relevant information om sexualitet genom omfattande, kvalitativ och tillgänglig och SRHR och hiv information och tjänster främst för unga människor för att förbättra situationen som beskrivs ovan.
Projektmål: Förbättrad SRHR och hiv situation för barn och ungdomar i östra och södra Afrika. För att nå detta mål kommer projektet ha följande delmål: (1) Att främja tillgången till SRHR för barn, ungdomar och unga människor genom att tillhandahålla omfattande sexualundervisning, med fokus på gender. (2) Att öka tillgången till SRHR tjänster vid hälsokliniker för barn, ungdomar och unga människor. (3) Att skapa en gynnsam lagstiftning och politisk miljö genom att förespråka lagstiftning som främjar förverkligandet av SRHR av barn, ungdomar och unga människor i de utvalda länderna och på regional nivå. (4) Att förbättra hanteringen av kunskap och gemensamt lärande kring SRHR på regional nivå.
Projektet kommer att genomföras i åtta (8) länder i östra och södra Afrika (ESA) regionen. Länderna är Kenya, Malawi, Sydafrika, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia och Zimbabwe. Valet land har baserats på behov identifierade genom projektet, bedömning av den lokala kontexten samt prioriteringar på landsnivå. Vidare så har Rädda Barnens landkontor i dessa länder strategier med fokus på ungdomars SRHR. Regionala aspekter inkluderar utmaningar som begränsad kunskap om SRHR, högt antal tonårsgraviditeter, högt antal nya HIV-infektioner bland ungdomar, sociala och kulturella hinder för SRHR-tjänster och lagar som begränsar möjligheten att arbeta med de utmaningar som ungdomar står inför. I de utvalda länderna kommer projektet att komplettera och bidra till processer som har identifierats regionalt för att uppnå resultat samt bidra till SRHR strategins resultat. Genom detta multinationella tillvägagångssätt engagerar projektet ett antal länder samtidigt som projektet på ett samordnat sätt, också ger ett regionalt perspektiv och driver frågan om ungdomars tillgång till SRHR i regionala fora.

Save the Children proposes a project that will work towards improving Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights as a way of addressing some root causes of HIV/AIDS. The intervention will be responding to Sexual and Reproduction Health and Rights (SRHR) challenges faced by children, adolescents and generally young people in the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region. Young people in the ESA region continue to grapple with different health issues including those related to HIV and SRHR. And with recent studies showing the intricate link between HIV and SRHR, both of them key contributors to mortality and morbidity amongst young people, there is need for well- designed interventions to address these two areas among young people. The project will work towards mitigating or providing an enabling environment for the mitigation of issues hampering young people’s good health which include: disconcertingly high HIV burden among young people especially girls; weak and fragmented health and social care systems which are vertical and insensitive to the needs of children and young people; low HIV testing, and a critical barrier to youth accessing care and treatment; low contraception rates for young people; high adolescent fertility; early sexual debut amongst adolescents; high prevalence of risky behaviour including unprotected sex, multiple concurrent partnerships, transactional and intergenerational sexual relations; inadequate sexuality information and knowledge; high rates of unintended pregnancies amongst girls; high levels of maternal mortality among young mothers; early marriages for young women and girls; and a reluctance and sometimes inability of parents and caregivers to communicate with children all aspects of sexuality, and thus a lack of SRHR education for all ages. The project will invest in building processes that will lead to the provision of relevant, quality, accessible and comprehensive SRHR and HIV information and services mostly for young people to improve the situation above. The Project goal is : improved SRHR/HIV outcomes for children and young people in Eastern and Southern Africa. To reach this goal, the Project will have the following objectives: (i) To promote the SRHR of children, adolescents and young people through the provision of comprehensive sexuality education, with a focus on gender sensitive approaches (ii) To increase access of Children, adolescents and young people to clinical and non-clinical SRHR services including Community based services. (iii) To create an enabling legislative and policy environment through advocating legislation that promotes the realisation of the SRHR of Children, adolescents and young people in the selected countries and at regional level. (iv) To improve the management of tacit knowledge and shared Learning around SRHR at regional level. The project will work in eight (8) countries in the East and Southern Africa (ESA) region. The countries are Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The country selection has been based on the need of the identified project interventions in the local contexts as well as the identified priorities at country level and country office strategies focusing on young people’s SRHR, and the identified cross-cutting regional elements which include limited knowledge about SRHR, high teenage pregnancy rates, high HIV infections among young people, socio-cultural barriers to accessing services and a lack laws that are responsive to the challenges faced by young people.

The overall goal of the intervention is 'Improved Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) for children, adolescents and young people in East and Southern Africa' . The objectives of the intervention are: 1. Promoting the SRHR of children, adolescents and young people through the provision of comprehensive sexuality education focusing on gender sensitive approaches. 2. Increasing access for children, adolescents and young people to clinical and non-clinical SRHR services including community based services. 3. Creating an enabling legislative and policy environment in the selected project countries through advocating for legislation that promotes the realisation of the SRHR of children, adolescents and young people at the national and regional level. 4. Improving the knowledge management and shared learning on SRHR at regional level. The primary target group were children, adolescents and young people aged 5-18 years and secondary target groups included young people aged 19-24 years, with a focus on parents, teachers, community health providers, and community leadership including traditional and religious leaders and national governments.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The "Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (ASRHR) at the fore: Working with children and young people as agents of change for better health outcomes” project was conceptualised based on the in-depth assessment that was conducted in 2016 to identify gaps and remaining priorities on sexual and reproductive health and rights for children, adolescents and young people in Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA). The gap assessment report identified four main issues to focus on: Policy environment : Translating sexual and reproductive health and rights policies into action. Structures and institutions that can support programme development: Building strong partnerships at local and national regional level for effective sexual and reproductive health and rights programming. Capacity of teachers, health workers and community workers: Mentorship and support to ensure effective delivery of relevant and age-appropriate comprehensive sexuality education. Gaps in youth sexual and reproductive health and rights service provision in the target communities. The gaps above informed the development of the project objectives and desired outcomes. The project was implemented in 8 countries namely Kenya, Malawi, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. During the period August 2016 - December 2017, project implementation was through the Save the Children International regional office and country offices. In the period January 2018 - October 2019, the project implementation modality was changed due to the Mexico City Policy (MCP) reinstatement in 2017 and because of the decision by Save the Children International to be MCP compliant. The project implementation was then transitioned to Save the Children Sweden Regional ASRHR Hub (hosted by Save the Children South Africa) in collaboration with selected 13 local partners (CBOs and CSOs) that were non-compliant to MCP in the eight project countries. Significant strides were made to reach children, adolescents and young people (CAYP) with relevant and comprehensive sexual and reproductive health and rights information. During the three-year period of project implementation (August 2016 - October 2019): - 2,938,378 CAYP were reached directly and indirectly . Out of this figure 391,919 CAYP were reached directly (211,437 females and 180,482 males). Direct reach was defined as making sure that the child has been engaged with for at least four hours of CSE activities and learning. Indirect was defined as the child receiving information from a material developed by Save the Children or an implementing partner and also if the child receives CSE information from an adult trained by Save the Children or an implementing partner . - The project also directly reached adults within the circle of care of CAYP including parents, teachers, caregivers, guardians, community gate keepers (religious and traditional leaders) totalling 285,947 (145,874 females and 140,100 males). - The process oriented approach (POA) trainings created a critical mass of 1,378 (769 females and 609 males) key social change agents (teachers, parents and care givers in different communities in the project countries. These change agents will continue to provide CSE and information, to generate more discourse about SRHR in schools, communities and access SRHR services. - A total of 71, 696 health workers trained in SRHR for CAYPs (617 reached directly and 71 079 reached indirectly) - Additionally, the Save the Children Sweden Regional ASRHR Hub, was consulted to provide technical input into the development of the SADC sexual and reproductive health and rights strategy at country level, feeding in the experiences and expertise from partners in the different project countries i.e. The CSO Forum before the second session in 2018 of the African Charter of the Rights and Welfare of the Child Commission focused on ASRHR for the first time in and made specific recomendations that were facilitated by the new Ugandan partner organisation Reproductive Health Uganda (RHU). - Lastly, the Regional ASRHR Hub hosted the learning and exchange symposium in Lusaka, Zambia in 2019 to enable partners to share experiences and display CSE and SRHR interventions implemented in the eight project countries. The symposium was used as an opportunity to meaningfully learn and engage on how to effectively scale up SRHR programmes for CAYP.
